dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: ...on a BLACK WAVE - vast, oceanic, and coming right at u BEGIN TITLES. The wave is relentless, huge, menacing. We can't tell if is daytime or night because it simply obscures everything noisily. It sucks, it yawns, it roars. Then we realize... this massive wave of darkness is actua just a RUN-OFF of dirty black WATER alongside the edge of Interstate. We PULL OUT OF IT now... ...to find concrete, and garbage, and weeds. END TITLES. 1   EXT. DITCH - OFF THE INTERSTATE - 4:30 A.M. Amongst the refuse is a discarded MILK CARTON, resting on back. The carton asks "Have You Seen Me?" above a photogr face that's been obscured by grime. Yellowing newspaper, old Coke cans, Twinkie wrappers... i that bed of untended weeds. A hollow Texas wind blows thr it all. We stay with the carton... Then that hollow wind gains speed... and a deep RUMBLE gr in the distance, becoming a ROAR. The yellowed newspaper off and whips past us. ...as an 18-WHEEL MACK TRUCK blows by, just a blur in the corner of our frame, doing 75 in the pre-dawn darkness. Then, the truck is gone, and the rush of air dissipates. milk carton, the coke cans... they lie undisturbed. A LIGHT RAIN begins to fall... and some of the grime wash away from that milk carton, revealing a face. A child. "H You Seen Me?" It's heartbreaking. TILT UP... to take in the vast flatness of Texas' I-35: concrete forever. In the distance, gray highway yields to black STORMCLOUDS gathering silently over endless prairie A vertical vein of LIGHTNING streaks through one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a spoon, stirring a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAROLD SPECK sits: mid 40's, pleasant face. A family man. Reads "Rod and Reel" magazine. Has a SALESMAN'S CASE by h side. Around him is a TRUCK-STOP in twilight: Truckers at the counter, Elvis on the wall, a "Drink Bud! mirror. The WORLD SERIES can be heard on a RADIO...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Top that off for ya, Hon? That's DOLLY, a waitress, (50, been here too long.) Speck looks up, smiles thinly, "No." Dolly heads off. Speck ret to his article, underlining a particular passage. ...until a MAN seats himself, suddenly, in the seat oppos Speck's. Speck reacts, startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus... The MAN's name is O'RYAN. We only see PIECES of him: his his hands, a stain on his parka...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's in the case?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're always lugging that case around. I'm curious. Speck looks around: there are plenty of empty tables in h So why is this guy bothering me???

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you sell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm... in restaurant supplies. I didn't get your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must travel a lot, huh? Speck is looking for Dolly, a Manager, anyone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whole country, or just hereabouts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mean to be rude but--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's your wife feel about it? That spun things a bit. Speck pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She must get lonely, with you gone all the time. Does she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you get lonely? Speck's so thrown now he can't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya miss fucking her, Harold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I don't know who you are but you can't-- O'Ryan silences him... by holding up a piece of paper. On is a DRAWING. The image faces away from us. But Speck can it in rich detail. And his eyes go wide. We catch GLIMPSES: The color of flesh. A body-part. Looks a rendering of a young, naked WOMAN. And, just like that, Speck finds himself STARING. Glued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did it myself. It's sort of a hobby. (no reply) I've got more. Would you like to see them? O'Ryan lowers it and slides a SECOND DRAWING over... Spec speechless, transfixed. Can't look away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me: those jokes about the traveling salesman and the farmer's daughter - are they true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Speck remains silent) Here. This one's my favorite. O'Ryan slides over DRAWING #3. Again, we don't get to see And we still haven't seen all of O'Ryan's face. But we can see Speck, and his reaction. Utter horror. In he recoils so violently that his coffee spills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really says it all, wouldn't you agree?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a... You're sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a matter of opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sick! He rises, leaving the drawings behind. We STAY WITH HIM a crosses the diner - deeply unsettled. He reaches the Mana (MEL, balding, 50, in no mood) at the register.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm-hmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm having a problem - with another customer. I'd like you to ask him to leave, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's-- He turns, to point out O'Ryan. ...but the booth, suddenly, is empty. The guy has simply disappeared, taking those drawings with him. Speck tightens. Mel eyes him, annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speck hurries out to his Buick, checking over his shoulde repeatedly. Gets to the car, fumbles with his keys. They to the asphalt. He grabs them, opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speck guns the Buick. Interstate 35 flies by. The farther gets away from that Diner, the happier he'll be. ...until a strange SOUND gets his attention: it's WIND, a whistling through a ghost town. Hollow, varied - building falling off again. Wind. Trouble is, the windows in this Buick are up. Yet there it is again: a thin, hollow GHOST-TOWN WIND, whistling over his shoulder. He's heard it before - in ev Western he ever watched as a kid. But this wind is coming from his back-seat. The blood drains right out of Speck's face. Doesn't know should jam on the brakes or drive faster. He looks in his rear-view, catches a glimpse of a LATEX G snapping onto a hand. Dear God: O'Ryan is back there, mak that odd Ghost-Town wind sound. Whistling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sheer terror)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What-do-you-want?! What-do-you-want-with- me?! No reply. Instead, another gift appears from the back: a FOURTH DRAWING, tossed from the darkness into Speck's lap He looks down, registers the image... and SHRIEKS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a rest stop, next off-ramp. Pull into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have some money. It's not a lot but--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody wants your money, Harold. Just pull in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?! O'Ryan rises into frame now, like Nosferatu...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I don't wanna do this at 70 miles an hour. It could be dangerous. Speck finds the off-ramp. His breaths are shallow now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Mister - what do you want from me? O'Ryan's face: a knowing grin fans across it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the face of VIRGIL RAY STARKEY, on a bulletin board.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: We're looking at the F.B.I.'s "Ten Most-Wanted List." Sta is #7 on it. He's 40, white. His crime are listed as rape murder, kidnapping. THOMAS MACKELWAY stares at Starkey's image. At the eyes.. Mackelway is 34, bred for success - bred for stardom in f a whiz at everything he's ever attempted. So what the hell is he doing in Wichita Falls, Texas...? EIGHT AGENTS, in cubicles, with a ring of outer offices. phones, lousy take-out options, hardly a dream gig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a spot set up for you, Tom. That's RICK CHARLTON: late 40's, thinning hair, friendly. Charlton heads around a corner. Mackelway follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms. Potter's the nice girl you met at the desk. She puts a package together for all the new agents, things to know about the area, help with finding apartments and such. This one's yours: Charlton stops at a CUBICLE: Carpeted walls, formica desk corner of dull Hell. Mackelway eyes it, fighting dread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so different from Dallas, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fuck yes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. An abandoned SPORTS PAGE tells us about that World Series we must be mid-October. Charlton heads out. Mackelway thr briefcase on to the desk, setting up his world: A framed picture of himself and his BROTHER, ages 10 and on a childhood camping trip. Address book, coffee-warmer, calendar, a baseball covered with autographs. He opens up a drawer, and casually tosses two bottles of BUFFERIN into the back of it. ...but first grabs four tablets from one of the bottles, and throws them down his throat, as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya like Frito Pies? Mackelway turns. BILL GRIEVES stands here, holding a whit grease-stained paper-bag. Grieves is Mackelway's age, not quite as ambitious. But solid, decent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno. What are they? Grieves pulls out a greasy concoction that's wrapped up l semi-burrito. Pure Texas. Tosses it to Mackelway:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to the minors. Grieves passes by with a faint smile, handing out lunch t few other agents. Mackelway eyes the still-wrapped Frito God, get me outta here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BRIEF MONTAGE: Mackelway, in his cubicle, watching as T OTHER AGENTS take calls, strap on guns, head out on assignment. Men in motion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Mackelway's land-locked, writing up an Auto-Theft rep It's drudgery, but he's meticulous about it, deleting the "beige" and replacing it with "tan." His head is throbbing - not an unusual circumstance for h But after lingering for a half-second on that "Most-Wante List" again? Starkey? It's a wound...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mackelway struggles with a COFFEE MACHINE that's unfamili him. Filter, water, grounds, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. Lemme do that. He turns. This is KATIE POTTER. She's 25, friendly, under challenged by her job. Been here two years. In two second she's got the thing percolating. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes some experience. He shrugs, not feeling too smooth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Mackelway, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm-hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fax came in for you. It's the room next door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Thanks. He rises, heads for the "fax room"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A former closet, converted into useful space. FIVE FAX MACHINES sit on stands, sharing a surge protector. One fa machine is printing. Mackelway approaches it. Six pieces of paper await him. The first is a TOP-SHEET, written by hand: "Attention: Agent Thomas Mackelway, FBI Resident Agency - Wichita Falls." No sender named. He looks beneath the top sheet - at Page One of the fax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young BOY stares back at him, his face photostatically copied. Across the top, also-handwritten: "HAVE YOU SEEN At the bottom of the sheet, typed, we read: "Jason Corey, Age 14. Ht. 5'1", Wt. 130, Eyes Brn, Hair B Last Seen: Riverside, Ca. Date of Disappearance: 10-16-99 Mackelway eyes the face, then the vitals. No idea why thi sent to him. Then he looks at Page Two. A young WOMAN stares back at him this time. Another faxed photo. Another "HAVE YOU SEEN ME?" scrawled across the to it. And, at the bottom of the sheet: "Anna Casitas, Age 22. Ht. 5'6", Wt. 125, Eyes Brn, Hair Last Seen: Macon, Ga. Date of Disappearance: 5-6-00." The other three faxes are more of the same: Pictures and vitals. Faces. Facts. "HAVE YOU SEEN ME?" He looks at the bottom of the transmissions, finds the fa number of the sender. Dials it. All he hears back is the grainy shriek of a dedicated fax line. He eyes the faxes again. It's not alarming, but it's odd. Charlton emerges from his office, shouting:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mackelway! You gonna sit on your ass all day, or do you wanna do something? Mackelway's out of this room in an instant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your standard roadside rest-stop: a parking lot with weed poking through it and bathrooms you wouldn't go near. Tho STORMCLOUDS we saw earlier are CLOSER now... POLICE CARS and HIGHWAY PATROL MOTORCYCLES fill this site Charlton's FBI SEDAN pulls up. He and Mackelway get out. Two men approach: SHERIFF HARRY DYLAN, 50; and his deputy GRANGER, a gangly, baby-faced pup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afternoon, Rick. (Charlton nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like a robbery/homicide. Body's over that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gestures toward a ravine, where a TOW TRUCK is current lowering a winch toward an abandoned vehicle. It is Harold Speck's Buick, nose-down in the ravine, teet on a rock, like the balanced scales of justice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya run the plates? Charlton eyes Mackelway: "Easy, Hot-shot." Mackelway nods reminding himself to remember his new rank. Dylan hands a preliminary report to Charlton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fella's name is Harold Speck. Traveling salesman, from Abilene. Charlton eyes the report, then hands it to Mackelway. The hierarchy is being made clear. Very. Mackelway turns: this ravine runs right up against a SIGN reads "Welcome to Texas" on one side and "You are now lea Oklahoma" on the other. A vehicle, left right on the state-line. Odd... Then, a NOISE: that Tow-Truck WINCH, grinding badly. It's about to yank the Buick out of this ditch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (it blurts out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Before Charlton can react, Mackelway is running across th weed-choked lot, zeroing in on the TOW-TRUCK DRIVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Driver, JUMBO, is operating the winch from a hydrauli handle on the back of the truck. Mackelway barrels in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck're you doing?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it look like, Bud? Mackelway reaches past Jumbo and hits the "Stop" button himself. The winch shuts down. Mackelway turns. A handful LOCAL COPS stand atop this ravine, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys ever heard of evidentiary procedure? No one replies. Charlton approaches. Mackelway tightens, expecting a reprimand for overstepping his bounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Sir. There wasn't time. Charlton eyes the car. Then Mackelway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did the right thing, Agent Mackelway. Let's have a look. Charlton starts down the embankment. Mackelway doesn't, hanging back as he eyes the TRACKS this Buick made before tumbling. Something about them... He pulls a small CAMERA from his pocket, a Minox. Snaps o few photos of the scene - the Buick, the ravine, those tr some FOOTPRINTS alongside them. Then he heads down the 15-foot embankment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an ugly sight. Speck is inches from us, but his head facing in the other direction, twisted unnaturally. Mackelway kneels beside the open window, pulls out some gloves, puts them on. He will not lean on the car, or eve breathe on it, his caution around evidence obvious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that? Charlton is opposite him, outside the passenger-side wind pointing at the DRAWING that O'Ryan had tossed onto Speck lap. It lies face down on the seat. But something's been FINGER-PAINTED on the back of it: A RED CIRCLE, with a SLASH through it. Charlton begins to reach for it, when:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to stop him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir? Charlton stops. Mackelway indicates: "Gloves."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlton eyes him. It's irritating being corrected by a g you outrank, especially when he's right. MACKELWAY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sort of a... stickler for procedure. CHARLTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I imagine you would be. That was a jab, but we don't know it yet. Charlton puts o gloves. Mackelway snaps off a few more shots with that Mi looking over the rest of this car, as: GRANGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aloud) Hey Jumbo. Toss me down a crowbar. Granger's by the trunk. Before Mackelway can comment, Jum has tossed a CROWBAR down from the top of the embankment: ten-pound hunk of iron, flying right at us. Everybody ducks... as it CLANGS on the roof of the Buick. Jumbo shrugs. JUMBO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said toss it. Mackelway shakes his head. "Shitkicker." Granger grabs th crowbar. He's just about to open the trunk as: MACKELWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it a second. Granger pauses. Mackelway crosses to the trunk, and snaps a few shots with the Minox. Something catches his eye, along the line of the TRUNK. H kneels closer... An odd RESIDUE, crusty and hard, has for thin line on top of the paint in a single post. He takes out a VIAL, and scrapes some of the residue into Then he sniffs it. Pauses... MACKELWAY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smells like... clove. He looks to Granger: now you can open the trunk. DYLAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: Mackelway) Where the hell'd you find this guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Field Office. Dallas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well now... (Charlton shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what the hell's he doin' here? That one is left unanswered. Granger opens the trunk. Mackelway and the others look inside... There, they find restaurant supplies: napkin dispensers, shakers, ketchup dispensers, a short-order wheel... And a fishing reel, tackle-box, a kid's bicycle helmet. Mackelway eyes it all, but his instincts tell him there's nothing significant here. So he returns to Speck's body. He leans in, lifts Speck's head a few inches away from th steering wheel. Gently. ...which is when we learn that Speck's EYELIDS have been off. It's gruesome, but Mackelway notes it calmly. Charlt leans in, gets a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ... Mackelway is expressionless. But something about these LI EYES draws him closer. He leans in, then BAM! We are rock into a series of dark, disjointed images:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems like we're standing in a field of TALL WHEAT; we ca say for sure. Everything's wet, wind-whipped. A MUZZLE FLASH... Someone just fired a gun. We slump hard the ground. Then we look up. Mackelway stands over us, his face wet with rain. Then, j as quickly, those IMAGES VANISH and we are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We start on the EYES OF O'RYAN. Cross-Dissolve to a pad o paper, on a DESK. Scrawled on the pad is a WAVY LINE. He the tip of that pen upon it, for a few seconds, as if expecting to get some kind of pulse from it. Here come those IMAGES again: wet wheat, a muzzle flash, Mackelway. Choppy, disjointed, dark. Then they cease...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and O'Ryan begins to DRAW, hurriedly. Only half of his is visible to us, but we can tell that his concentration total. His pen continues its furious work, a spasm of activity, the SOUNDS of that vision bleed in: the gun-shot, the rai the wind. They're all alive in O'Ryan's mind... And that DRAWING takes shape quickly: The wheat field, th gun, Mackelway. Then, the pen is set down. The drawing is complete. O'Ryan eyes it calmly, then checks his watch, jotting dow exact time and date on to the drawing. Then he slips it i folder marked, "MACKELWAY."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Picket fence, a swing on the porch, a lawn that needs mow A LINE OF PEOPLE file in, each bringing food... and tissu cry into.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shocked faces. Food on unmatching trays. Speck's wife - J 40 and frayed - sits in a chair, immobile. FRIENDS and FA mill about, tending to her. KIDS hover. Two of them, a 4-YEAR-OLD BOY and an 8-YEAR-O GIRL, sniff back tears as people offer condolences. But the focus here is Jan - her grief. She's shaking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Speck? She looks up. O'Ryan crouches down, to eye-level, one of faces in here. Jan half-nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wanted to offer my condolences. (takes her hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know him well but... I think Harold was a much more complex man than people realized. Jan is so raw that anything about Speck touches her now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through tears)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was, wasn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry for your loss, ma'am. She sniffs back a tear, thanks him with a smile. O'Ryan extends his hand to her. She takes it. He moves off. Beside her is a FRAMED PORTRAIT of Speck. We blow past it into the BLACK CREPE that is adorning the corner of the portrait's FRAME, and: BAM! We're rocketed back into a set of odd IMAGES again:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time, everything before us is a blur of gray. We hea that wet wind. We hear our own heavy BREATHING, as if we running somewhere... a VOICE, rising above the wind, seem be saying:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please... The sound echoes oddly, as if bouncing off a satellite somewhere, or a distance of time and space. Then the sound and the soupy grayness VANISH. This vision ended. When we pop back out of it, we're TIGHT on Mackelw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mackelway sits behind the wheel of his Chevy Yukon, parke between two big-rigs in the lot of the "All-American Dine Sky looks black tonight. It rumbles... And that soupy gray vision we just heard and saw... It wa his. He pulls four more Bufferins out of a bottle in his pocke Slugs them down. This headache is a constant. Then he get of the Yukon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mackelway enters, spots Charlton at a booth - sitting opp a WOMAN, her back to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mackelway approaches. The Woman doesn't turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agent Mackelway. I was 'bout to introduce you, but I understand that won't be necessary. Mackelway doesn't get it... until the WOMAN turns. She is AGENT FRAN KULOK. 35, sharp, pretty when she allows herse be. But with a guard that never comes down. Mackelway has some history with her, so he tries not to r It takes some effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems your former office has decided we might need some help on this one. So they sent out Agent Kulok.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran. That was terse, from both of them. Charlton takes note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess we're skipping the tearful reunion. Have a seat, Tom. Mackelway sits opposite Fran. She folds her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's things back at the ranch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Movin' right along. That might've been a dig; Charlton can't tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Whadda we know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Picked up a foot-print in the back seat of Speck's car, size-and-a-half bigger than Speck's. Just like that, Fran is piping up. Mackelway's unoffended

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Kay. FRAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wounds on Speck's throat indicate that he was strangled from behind... I think our guy waited for him in the backseat, sprung this on him once the car was moving. She slides that FOURTH DRAWING to Charlton - giving us ou first look at it.

dialogues.speaker: THE DRAWING
dialogues.text: ...a STEAMER-TRUNK, lined with plastic. Inside it are lar ZIPLOC BAGS. Inside the bags are BODY PARTS. It's realized so accurately that it looks more like a photograph. No wonder it horrified Speck so deeply.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOOTH
dialogues.text: Charlton eyes it without reaction. FRAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lab picked up talcum traces on the edges of the paper, consistent with powdered gloves. (Charlton nods) So he gets the dropped in his lap, it spooks him, and the car winds up in the ravine. Plausible enough, until: MACKELWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so, no. I think it was pushed. FRAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How ya figure? MACKELWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The look of the tracks. Foot-prints near the embankment. Without embellishing any further, he slides over the PHOTOGRAPHS that he took this morning with the Minox: tir tracks, foot-prints. She eyes them. Then she eyes Mackelway. Charlton notes the tension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. So our guy likes to draw pictures of body parts and then spring 'em on people. What's that get us? (they're silent) That's what I thought. There is plenty going unsaid here between Mackelway and F Charlton has no time for it. CHARLTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. 'Fore I forget. This came in for you: He tosses a 9-by-12 ENVELOPE at Mackelway, who opens it. sheets of paper slide out. First one we see is the TOP SHEET of a FAX: same hand-wri inscription as the last one: "Attention, Agent Thomas Mackelway, FBI Resident Agency, Wichita Falls." Okay. This is twice now. He knows what will be under this sheet without even looking. But here's Page One: A photo of a middle-aged African-American WOMAN. Across t top of the photo, in hand-writing: "HAVE YOU SEEN ME?" And typed on the bottom: "Tanya Green. Age 42. Ht. 5'9", 165, Eyes Blk, Hair Blk. Last Seen: Ames, Iowa. Date of Disappearance: 3-22-97." The following four sheets bring four more faces: men, wom young, old. Four more HAVE YOU SEEN ME's. But before he can think it through, he hears: MANAGER (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about time. They turn. That came from the NIGHT MANAGER: a humorless named LES. He's looking at the front door, through which has just entered. Pink cowboy boots tonight. DOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't start in on me, Les. I couldn't get the pickup started and Harlan took the Dodge. The Manager now throws a glance at the three feds in the booth. Dolly stops short, taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy Hell. My one shot at winding up on "Cops" and I'm in my weekday boots!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly and Mel sit opposite Mackelway and Fran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a quiet guy. Normal. Liked to read fishing magazines. Not much of a tipper. Is that a lousy thing to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine. Mel rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can you tell us about the other man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I said, I never really saw him. Harold came up, complainin' about the guy - but time I turned, he was gone. FRAN                      MACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at Dolly:)               (at Dolly:) Could you de--            Did you get a-- They each stop short, waiting for the other to yield. Fin Mackelway nods, "Go ahead."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you describe him, Ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. He was... Dolly pauses, her face scrunching a bit. Troubled...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's weird. Guy was in here better part of an hour. We had a real pleasant chat... But I can't remember a thing about him. For the life of me. Couldn't even tell you what color his eyes were. She shrugs apologetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happen to see what he was driving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That one's easy. It's still in the lot. (they perk up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bonneville out there with the awful paint job. She gestures to the lot, where an old PONTIAC BONNEVILLE its paint stripped down to the primer. Bingo. Fran and Mackelway eye it, then one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran and Mackelway emerge, heading for the Bonneville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ought to work out some kind of protocol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interviews. Witnesses. Looks pretty silly, our talking over one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. I'll handle them from now on. He doesn't argue. They come to a stop at that Bonneville, stripped down to its primer. Time to work... Two agents, all instinct. We see them study things, detai their minds always churning... Mackelway pulls out his Mi snaps off a few more shots. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trunk's ajar. She turns. Sure enough, the Bonneville's trunk is ajar. Mackelway approaches, cautiously. He doesn't have gloves on him, so he uses his jacket pock protect against prints. He opens the trunk. First thing he sees is that SYMBOL again: a circle-with-a slash-through-it... staring right at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this time, it's been carved into somebody's back. Mackelway stares. So does Fran. Before them lies a body, stripped to the waist: a chunky middle-aged MAN. Dead. Mackelway sighs. Things just got tougher...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold Speck lies on a table. A BESPECTACLED CORONER exam him. Victim #2, BARNEY FULCHER, lies on another, his ampl frame yet to be examined. The lights are out, but that Coroner wears a FLUORESCENT with a MICROPHONE pinned to his gown. He speaks into it w quiet monotone: anatomical terms, etc. Mackelway and Fran are here... watching. Mackelway is particularly focused on Fulcher's face. His EYELIDS, we n see, have also been torn off. Hmmmm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why eyelids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No other signs of torture here. Why take somebody's eyelids off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they can't blink. She sighs, aloud: "I know that already, Asshole." Coroner keeps his head down, speaking into that microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a metaphor - to make certain the victim sees... or to make certain that we see something. (she's silent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or maybe it's just a fuck-you. Coroner continues his monotone narration... then crosses the sink. That puts him out of earshot. So:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Fran, quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about Don.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thrown)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not wearing your ring anymore. That was an attempt at kindness. She knows that. Still, s eyes her left hand, self-consciously, while Mackelway los himself in those lidless eyes of Fulcher's... Then there's a KNOCK AT THE GLASS WINDOW BEHIND THEM. They turn. Charlton stands on the other side of a GLASS WINDOW, in a VIEWING ROOM adjacent to this Morgue. He pre a piece of paper up against the glass. On it, in typed bold letters at the top, we read: "MATCHE ONE OF ONE." Below that we see that Circle-with-the-slash through-it. This is a FAX, which Charlton's just received. He points further down on the fax at what look like little squiggle first, until we move in to discover it is a hand drawn st map. The ink bleeds a bit due to a poor fax transmission. Thos scrawled lines take us to "The Hope House," in Oklahoma C At the bottom a scribbled name, "David Dyson," and a cont number. Moving closer to the glass, Mackelway nods. He just got a break...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CHOIR of FIRST AND SECOND GRADERS stands before a schoo assembly. The rest of Boulder Elementary's student body f the seats in here, along with FACULTY MEMBERS. Everybody's weeping. A framed picture of Barney Fulcher s on a stand, with candles around it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A-may-zing Grace, How sweet the sound--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the back, some of the TOWNSFOLK have gathered for this assembly, touched. O'Ryan stands among them. No expressio his face at all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A three-story Victorian residence in decay, next door to CHURCH/SOUP KITCHEN in the middle of Oklahoma City's Skid Rain falls. The street is still. Mackelway approaches this halfway-house. A few lights shi within, and the blue glow of a tv. Upstairs can be heard strident, off-key voice of somebody singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door is open. Through a SCREEN DOOR, Mackelway see an old-fashioned "foyer." He knocks. Waits. Two sounds dominate: the buzz from that tv, and the strid singing, which we realize is an a capela version of "La V Loca" audible through an open bedroom window. But no one's coming to answer the door, and it's wide ope anyway... So Mackelway enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TV room is to his left. There, a single 35 year-old DRUNK TRANSIENT (we'll call him "PIPER") sits, watching "Behind Music" on VH1. Tonight's subject? Leif Garret... Piper doesn't look up, or acknowledge Mackelway at all. R he INCREASES THE TV VOLUME to drown out the singing upsta which seems to be intentionally off-key. Torn couches, stained carpet, cracked window. Posters and fliers on the walls. 10 BEDROOMS upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agent Mackelway? Mackelway turns. Descending a creaking stairway is DAVID DYSON: 50, lean, with a friendly smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are staring at a BASEMENT WALL that has been covered, to ceiling, with 1,000 identical renderings of that same symbol: the CIRCLE-WITH-A-SLASH-THROUGH-IT. 1,000 of them, in bright red paint, against pitch black enamel. Only a machine could have achieved this kind of repetition. Or a maniac. This basement is leaky, drafty, poorly lit. But it's also quiet: the sound of that awful singing upstairs has been by the basement door and the rain itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin spent hours down here. Mackelway takes it all in, every corner of this basement. notes a row of standing GYM LOCKERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: lockers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he have access to those?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. They're staff-only.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind opening them for me? Dyson shrugs; he thinks it's a waste of time - but he'll it. Mackelway follows him across the dank room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was here... seven years you said?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off and on. It's not uncommon for our guests to vanish for months at a time. Dyson works a combination lock on the first locker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ran the name through our database, just to be sure. There's never been an Agent Benjamin O'Ryan in the Bureau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... but as elaborate fantasies go, it was one of my favorites. (fondly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he always seemed so sincere about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dyson half-chuckles; he always liked the guy... He throws the locker. Inside, nothing. Mackelway indicates the next locker. Dyson works the combination. MACKELWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what you called him? Benjamin? DYSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's what he wished to be called. Locker #2 is opened - also empty. Only one locker left. DYSON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: locker #3) That one's mine. Mackelway shrugs: "Sorry, it has to be opened." Dyson sig then works the combination. Mackelway waits. Locker #3 is opened. Inside, nothing incriminating: a swe some old junk, two trophies. Dyson eyes him: "See?" Macke nods. Dyson shuts the locker. Mackelway looks to that wall: 1,000 copies of the circle- a-slash-through-it. No idea what they signify... DYSON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He painted one of the walls in his room, too. MACKELWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I see it? DYSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've painted it over. MACKELWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still, might be helpful. Dyson heads for the stairs. They're wooden slats with mor basement-junk stored below: old sporting equipment, an ol vaccuum cleaner, broken chairs, rusted patio furniture. Mackelway follows. They climb... MACKELWAY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. They stop. Something just caught Mackelway's eye, visible beneath these stairs: a BOX, with a bucket of PAINT stick out of it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mackelway climbs under the stairs, crouching down, pushin aside all of the aforementioned junk. He grabs the box. Sure enough, that bucket once held red paint - same color O'Ryan used to cover that wall. There's also a bucket of PAINT here. And some used brushes. Mackelway brings the box into the meager light. We get a INSIDE IT now. So does Dyson. Inside, beneath the paint-buckets, we see a few TV GUIDES yo-yo, a football. Then a BOOK on TRIBAL RITUAL AND TRANC Mackelway grabs it, eyes it. He flips through a few pages - odd images: a TRIBESMAN wi eyes rolling back in his head, strange rites, etc. Mackelway sets the book down. Then, amidst the other mate in this box, he spots a large folded MAP. He grabs it, begins to unfold it. We see that this map's written on, in pen. Cities on it have been CIRCLED. But before we can get a good look at it, Mackelway spots something else, at the bottom of this box, a shocker: A photograph of himself. It takes him a second to realize what he's looking at. Bu there it is, a NEWSPAPER PHOTO, of Agent Thomas Mackelway It is part of a FRONT-PAGE STORY, dated July of this year concerning the trial and release...of Virgil Ray Starkey. on the F.B.I.'s Most-Wanted List... Dyson can't help but notice the picture of Mackelway. Mackelway stares. Suddenly we JUMP BACK IN TIME, NINE MON for a brief, choppy FLASHBACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're RUNNING, dashing between two buildings of chipped-a hearing nothing but the sound of our own breathing and th thuds of our own heavy feet. This is Matamoros, Mexico, a shit-hole of a border town. Squalor and sin. We find a DRUNK MEXICAN TEEN. He nods: " is the place," and sticks out his palm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mackelway stares at that newspaper: Starkey - rapist, murderer, whose case was just thrown out of court - a stu failure for all involved. ...as we RESUME MACKELWAY'S FLASHBACK - Matamoros again..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad-lighting, drunk patrons in a CIRCLE, and a DONKEY-SHO taking place on a bare stage. Feels like we've stepped in some kind of evil carnival. It's dizzying. Among the crowd: Virgil Starkey, in an ugly drunken binge only guy in here who isn't cheering or laughing. Suddenly our GUN is pointed right at his head. Starkey freezes, caught. Some of the PATRONS around him f somewhere else to stand... But the show goes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That ARTICLE gives us more detail now, the reason Starkey case was thrown out of court. It is this: The F.B.I. Agent on the case had made a mistake in "evidentiary procedure." Hence, Mackelway's picture. On his face, we GO BACK TO ANOTHER MEMORY: six months ago

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three months have passed since the arrest in Matamoros. N Mackelway sits in this courthouse ANTEROOM, adjacent to a courtroom. Four sour PROSECUTORS surround him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'you understand how fucked we are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaving a tissue sample in the care of a Mexican lab? Are you fucking kidding me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They assured me that they understood protocol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well guess what? They didn't. And this prick's gonna walk, ten murders or not. That registered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beneath this newspaper article are OTHER ARTICLES, all concerning Starkey: his crimes, his capture, all of it. Mackelway's memory just got stoked again:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mackelway emerges from that courthouse anteroom, whipped. The hall's busy with MEDIA and other traffic. First face sees is Fran, who sits on a bench, (wedding ring ON). Her say how lousy she feels for him. It almost helps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door bursts open and Mackelway storms in. No need to composed now; he's alone in here. He crosses to a paper-t dispenser, SLUGS IT. Stares in the mirror. He's livid, embarrassed, frustrated - can barely look at own reflection. Then he hears LAUGHTER, behind him. He turns. Out of the darkness of a badly-lit STALL, Virgil Starkey emerges, coming into view under a single light. Beside him is a GRIM COP, his chaperone. Starkey passes b Mackelway, almost snickering. Then he's gone. Mackelway s his eyes tight. His head is pounding. END FLASHBACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mackelway stares... at a record of his deepest wound. But the hell is it doing in the locker of a transient?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mackelway leans in, looking around. A bed. A small end-ta Bathroom. A window without bars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From down the hall we hear the sound of a PHONE RINGING, a FAX transmission. An old fax machine begins to whine noisily, creaking. It's a distraction. But Mackelway's focus is in this room. The walls have bee painted. But there's a hint of barely-perceptible color beneath one of them. Rain from a LEAKY ROOF is causing so the new paint to peel a bit. A BUCKET collects drops in the center of the room. The fe in here is damp, mildewy, creepy. Mackelway remains in th doorway... then backs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you fellas're never unaccounted for, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mackelway turns, a bit startled. Dyson is approaching, FA hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Dyson extends six pages. On the TOP-SHEET, written by han are the words: "Agent Thomas Mackelway, C/O Mr. David Dys Hope House" with a street address. And under that top sheet? Five more pages. Mackelway sighs, takes them from Dyson. Sure enough, he's staring at five more faces, five more fact sheets. Five m HAVE YOU SEEN ME's. But how would anyone know to send them here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything urgent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't look up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Dyson is glad to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mackelway descends, having had quite enough of this place Piper is where we left him, watching VH1 in the TV Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mackelway passes, eyeing those newly-faxed pages: five mo HAVE YOU SEEN ME'S... He reaches the door. PIPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever seen a fifty-foot shark? Mackelway stops, turns. MACKELWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry? PIPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty-foot shark. Ever seen one? MACKELWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. PIPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't mean there aren't any. Great. Mackelway reaches for the front door again. Then h halts. Maybe this guy can be helpful. Mackelway turns: MACKELWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know him? (Piper's silent) The guy who used to stay upstairs. "O'Ryan." Did you know him? PIPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Is he dead? MACKELWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't... PIPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said "Did." Is he dead? MACKELWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I mis-spoke. No, he's not dead... (a beat) You know him? Piper nods. Mackelway eyes him, then approaches, holding up a copy of image: the circle-with-slash-through-it. MACKELWAY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ever talk about this? A circle with a slash through it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Piper rises, crosses to us... leaning in unnecessarily cl It's unsettling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not a circle. It's a zero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. How do you know? Piper doesn't answer. Instead he simply starts whistling. But it's not a tune coming out of his mouth. It's that sa sound that O'Ryan made: A WHISTLING WIND, blowing through ghost town... Building, then falling again. Piper smiles, backing away, enjoying the theatricality of stifling a giggle... Then, suddenly, everything turns GRAINY, CHOPPY... We've jumped into a distorted, REMOTE POV of this same sc as if watching it through a crystal ball, or a broken len a distance of time and space... We see images, fragments: Piper, the tv, the sofa, Mackel face. Then all sound breaks up, and we are...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start on O'Ryan's EYES. Then a pad of paper. The spasm of pen, scrawling a LIST on to it: "Piper. TV. Whistling." W in another non-descript MOTEL ROOM. $29 a night. He holds down the point of his pen on a wavy line beside list of words, keeping it there for a few seconds, as if expecting to receive some kind of pulse from it. No more pulse. He has lost the "connection" that had some transported him. He notes his watch. Jots down the exact Slips the pad into that FOLDER: "Mackelway." Then he starts to DRAW - a hurried but accurate sketch of Mackelway and Piper, just as they stood during that conversation. The geography is fairly accurate. O'Ryan continues to draw. We CRANE OUT of this motel room find, on the street below:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A typical honky-tonk in a town called Sleeper, Missouri. across the street from O'Ryan's cheap motel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Low-lights, dust on the floor. Pool tables. LORETTA is a pretty 19-year-old who stands at the jukebox weighing her choices. She's got a thick curtain of hair, she wrangles with a CHIP-CLIP. It's a habit. She chooses a country-rock tune, then heads for the bar, walking to the beat. It's fun being 19 and beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BAR
dialogues.text: The BARTENDER'S a stocky guy with a broad smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: song)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little cute for my taste, but I can stand three minutes of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have a seven and seven, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven and seven. Got some i.d.? She half-laughs, as if she hasn't been carded in a decade throws that curtain of hair from one side to the other, r fastening that chip-clip. It's her best move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's in the car. No one's asked me for it for a couple years now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If ya hurry, you'll still catch the end of the song. She eyes him: are you really carding me? He smiles: nothi personal, Sugar. So she heads for the door. ...on her way, she passes a booth. In it we find a famili face - Virgil Ray Starkey... He remains still, as if he hadn't noticed her. But behind his eyes, something primal just took place. He rises, hea for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta walks to her VW Bug. Starkey exits the bar. She doesn't notice. We TILT UP: the lights are off in O'Ryan' motel room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It all happens pretty fast: That chip-clip hits the groun beside the open VW door. A battered PICK-UP speeds away, kicking up gravel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Loretta's eyes, wide with terror and dread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're off-road. Missouri's woods can be seen through the windshield. And Starkey is staring at us. Pawing at us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Mister... Starkey's hand shoots out, banging Loretta's head against window, hard. That makes things start to swim. Starkey te at her clothes, lowers himself on to her. She whimpers. WE CARRY THE SOUND OF IT INTO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is where you go when you've just moved to Wichita Fa and money's tight: spotty shag carpet, chipped Formica ki table, scuffed blinds. ...and one sleepless agent, having one lousy night. Mackelway sits on the edge of his bed, almost able to hea Loretta's helpless cries. Some nights are like this. His is POUNDING again. Down go four more Bufferin. Above him, covering the bedroom mirror, is the MAP he too from that Hope House basement. O'Ryan's map, UNFOLDED. It's HUGE: 6-feet-wide, 4-feet-tall, obscuring the mirror As we glimpsed while still in that basement, this map his written on, in pen. O'Ryan's notations cover it: Over a THUSAND CITIES on it have been CIRCLED, by hand, i RED. Each of those circled cities has a DATE written besi it, also in red: ("4/6," "5/19," "10-26," etc.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mackelway studies it, his face working. Another of those WHIMPERS from Loretta seems to hang, suspended. Mackelway shakes it off, certain that he's imagining it. He won't sleep a wink tonight. We LEAVE HIM, returning to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The attack continues, its terror unimaginable. Loretta so It hurts. Starkey's too powerful to fight off. We stay on face: dazed, her mind simply checking out. ...until a look of cognizance comes over her, brought on SHADOW that just passed by. Then the window behind Starkey simply EXPLODES. Glass flies everywhere, and TWO ARMS reach into the pick- They grab Starkey by the neck and yank him out of the pic his back sliced open by shards. He screams. She can't resist coming to the window, where she sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Starkey lies, face up. Shocked. Squirming. Bleeding. Stan over him, looming large as a Grizzly... is O'Ryan. A long HUNTING KNIFE extends from his hand. But his tone, to our great surprise, is conversational:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, listen, I'm sorta new in town. Ya know where I can find a good donkey show? Starkey has no idea how to respond to this maniac:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Forgot. Wrong country... In America animals have rights. (pointedly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't they, Virgil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the fuck should I know? O'Ryan half-smiles, then kicks Starkey right in the head. Loretta's eyes go wide. Another kick follows, to the ribs Then one to the groin. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at Loretta)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn around. He said that without looking at her. But he can tell that hasn't moved - too frightened. So he eyes her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn around! She turns away, lying face down on the seat, covering her head. No idea what kind of terror is to come next. We STA WITH HER... able only to hear what follows: The sound is animal, awful - like a pig being gutted - a horrible SQUEAL, covering the GRUNTS coming from O'Ryan. In goes the knife again, prompting another agonized cry f Starkey. Loretta's crying too: from fear, shock... She ke her face buried, shutting her eyes tight. The sounds of savagery fill the night. Then, one last gasp from Starkey... followed by an awful silence... and the assault is over. Loretta's too afraid to look up - certain that the maniac the knife will be coming after her next. But then she hears FOOTSTEPS, trailing away. So she rises peeking over the edge of the window. WE STAY ON HER FACE, she sees what's become of her attacker. Her horrified SCREAM fills the woods...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mackelway STARES out the window; seems like he just HEARD scream. Of course, that'd be impossible. He looks to that His PHONE RINGS. He eyes it, unsurprised...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Law enforcement VEHICLES surround the site. COPS, Grieves CORONER'S GUYS taking pictures. Loretta is sitting on the of an ambulance, being tended to. A COMPOSITE ARTIST sits beside her, trying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think the eyes are right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COMPOSITE ARTIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Narrower? LORETTA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they were... I don't really know. Composite Artist keeps trying, but his attempt doesn't lo anything like the face of O'Ryan. Charlton, meanwhile, stands over the body, mind racing. A Missouri Highway Patrol car pulls up. Mackelway steps o it. We follow him as he takes in the scene. A FLASHBULB illuminates Starkey's CHEST; is got a zero-wi a-slash-through-it. But Mackelway hasn't seen the guy's f yet. MACKELWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir? (Charlton turns) We got an i.d. yet? CHARLTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm-hmm. (Mackelway waits) Might wanna find yourself a fender. You're gonna need to sit down. (Mackelway's still waiting) It's Virgil Ray Starkey. Mackelway pales. We stay on him for a moment as it registers. The man he caught, and then lost, has killed again. No. God, no. MACKELWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (struggling for composure:) Starkey did this? CHARLTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Starkey's the one on the ground. Mackelway pauses, thinks he must've heard wrong. But he t toward the face, as ANOTHER FLASHBULB illuminates it, sea the image into the darkness. Starkey. Dead. His eyelids r away. Mackelway stares, stunned. Can't fucking believe it. MACKELWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breathless) My God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like looking at a ghost - a spectre that's been haun him, dead now... Mackelway pulls out his Minox, starts photographing, moving in on those LIDLESS EYES...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gonna make a wallet-size of that one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give him a break, Grieves. Mackelway doesn't comment. Just keeps snapping shots...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The number of HAVE YOU SEEN ME's has now grown, quite a b 45 PAGES sit stacked on Mackelway's desk. 45 victims. He the stack, rises. Heading for the Conference Room, he nearly bumps into Kat the Receptionist, rounding a corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Scuse me. She smiles. He carries the HAVE YOU SEEN ME's into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A room has been dedicated solely to those three murders. erasure board are the words: The "O'Ryan" Room. On one wall is the MAP Mackelway took from Hope House: ov thousand CITIES circled by O'Ryan himself. Mackelway puts down the stack of HAVE YOU SEEN ME's. Pick a box of YELLOW STICK-PINS, affixing them to the map - on every faxed face. Here's "Jason Corey, Age 14." Last seen in "Riverside, Ca

Sure enough, O'Ryan had circled "Riverside, Ca." on this Next to it he'd written "10-16." Mackelway sticks a yellow pin in Riverside. Next, the fax concerning "Anna Casitas, Age 22." Last See "Macon, Ga." on "5-6-00." Of course, O'Ryan had circled "Macon" too. Beside it he'd written "5-6." So Macon gets a yellow pin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mackelway continues, as: FRAN (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got nothing on the last fax. Mackelway turns. In comes Fran. FRAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Came from a business center at a Mariott in Dallas. Nobody saw who sent it. Mackelway nods. Then they both turn... Charlton enters th room. CHARLTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whadda we know about the map? MACKELWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It matches the faxes, Sir. Almost perfectly. Charlton approaches the map: 1,242 cities, circled in red Mackelway continues with the yellow pins: one for every H YOU SEEN ME? (45 of them so far.) Charlton eyes the stack. 45 HAVE YOU SEEN ME's... Then th map: 1,242 cities. Each with a DATE beside it. CHARLTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why's Greenville in blue? (Mackelway has put a yellow pin beside a dozen cities... tiny Greenville, Texas has a BLUE PIN beside it.) MACKELWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only city where the date on the fax and the date on the map didn't correspond. He pulls out a fax from the stack: a Korean boy named "St Kim. Age 16. Last Seen: Greenville, Tx. Date of Disappear
MACKELWAY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fax lists the date of disappearance as August 7. On the map he's written "10-
The DATE on O'Ryan's map reads "10-26" beside Greenville, So Greenville gets the only blue pin on this map. Charlton notes today's date: October 17...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any of these bodies been recovered?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two so far. Female, disappeared from Dayton, Ohio on April 12. And a male, Trenton, New Jersey, January 5th. On the MAP, Dayton's got "4/12" written beside it. Trento "1/5." Both have yellow pins in them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But both bodies were found over a thousand miles from where they'd last been seen. One in Montana, the other in Oregon. Got autopsy reports on both. Charlton looks to the table, where AUTOPSY REPORTS and AU PHOTOS sit - two victims we've never seen before. We see the VICTIMS photographed face up, face down, waist above, waist and below. Charlton gives the photos a curso glance, nothing more. But we notice something, on one of the bodies: the male f Trenton - an odd BURN MARK on his lower left calf. Looks almost symmetrical, horizontal across the calf...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either of the bodies have the zero on them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Sir. Charlton, frustrated, SHOVES THOSE AUTOPSY PHOTOS ASIDE. look to that MAP, a handful of yellow pins in it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...that same map, over a HUNDRED YELLOW PINS in it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's 8:30 at night. Mackelway is alone in here - staring the map. He's been doing a lot of that lately. The stack of HAVE YOU SEEN ME's has grown as well. Every of them corresponds to a yellow pin on the map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Some of the HAVE YOU SEEN ME's have arrived via U.S. MAI see a stack of ENVELOPES in a box, each sealed in PLASTIC each stamped and addressed to Mackelway.) Mackelway eyes the map, puzzling. Fran's right beside him Assorted papers and leads fill this room, including photo took himself with that Minox. FRAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you? MACKELWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? FRAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He could be sending these to any agent in any office in the country... But he's sending them to you. Why? Mackelway's been asking himself that same question lately MACKELWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. PHONE RINGS. She grabs it. FRAN (INTO PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Agent Kulok. (a beat) Who's calling? She hears the answer, then covers the phone. FRAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mackelway:) Do you know a professor named Daitz? Says he's from Tulane. MACKELWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eagerly) Yeah. Criminal Psych. I've been trading e- mails with him. FRAN (INTO PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One moment, please... She hands him the phone...

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: A beautiful campus, quiet tonight. In its center lies a v expensive structure - the Behavioral Sciences Building. T place goes on forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mackelway exits an elevator on the "B-1 Level." Corridors octopus their way from these elevators, confusing us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every door looks the same. Mackelway follows the numbers can't believe how long these hallways are. Turns a corner Air can be heard, moving through the corridor. But he has found the right number, at last. A tiny CARD fastened to a wall reads, "Dr. Emile Daitz, Professor Emeritus, Criminal Psychology." It also lists h office hours. Mackelway knocks at a door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor Daitz?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? Mackelway opens the door. Looks inside. Here sits O'Ryan, looking as much like a tweedy professor he can look. He rises, smiles warmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agent Mackelway. Come in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tiny, cramped hovel. Books, papers, and all of it jamme overflowing. Mackelway sits across from O'Ryan...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as "Daitz:")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The name of this theory was "Suspect Zero." (Mackelway nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The idea of Suspect Zero posits that if a serial killer were diabolical enough, he could traverse the country without ever being caught, killing randomly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a COLLECTION here in a glass case: ANCIENT WEAPON crude knives, swords, blow-darts. Mackelway notes them. O'RYAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, what makes a killer catchable? MACKELWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patterns, repetition of behavior. O'RYAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now imagine a killer with no patterns, no tell-tale fetishes, no rituals, no hidden desire to be caught. A perfect vessel of evil, killing without ever leaving a single meaningful clue in his wake... He'd be immune to capture, wouldn't he? Your task forces, your forensics teams - they'd be helpless. Mackelway looks over Daitz' bookshelf: volume after volum about evil, the devil, the minds of sociopaths, the histo serial-killers, ritual killers, tribal rites... MACKELWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that something you believe in, Professor? Evil? O'RYAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a citizen of the world, it's hard not to. Wouldn't you say? (Mackelway can't argue) Evil is all around us, I think - a part of the natural order of things. Like gravity. Like wind. A vast black wave, corrupting everything it touches. A virus invades a cell, causing it to dysfunction. Perfectly logical. But did it ever occur to you that something may have invaded that virus, something capable of using it to mutate so powerfully? Mackelway pauses, considering that. O'RYAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just because something's invisible to us doesn't mean it doesn't exist. Mackelway is silent: Something's off here. But he can't s for sure just yet what it is... O'RYAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever seen a fifty-foot shark?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wasn't just the echo of a question he's heard before was a red flag. A big one. Mackelway tightens. MACKELWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry? O'RYAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shark, as we know, will only attack humans if he runs out of food. But biologists have theorized that for a shark of fifty feet the ocean would be an endless buffet. He'd never run out of food, so he'd have no need to come to the surface. Consequently, we would never see him. Do you follow? (Mackelway doesn't) We'll never see one. But that doesn't mean they don't exist. Hence Suspect Zero. Mackelway eyes those books on evil, then those ancient weapons... Casually, almost imperceptibly, he reaches for sidearm, as O'Ryan continues: O'RYAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of my colleagues think I'm fascinated with evil. I think the truth is just the opposite: evil is fascinated with us. What better vehicle could there be for creating havoc in the world - what better instrument - than Man? We're vain, we're stubborn, we're deceitful, we have an imagination that is limitless in its perversions. Of course Evil keeps trying to harness us. Wouldn't you? The more he talks, the closer Mackelway comes to extracti that gun... Then, disturbing the silence, a KNOCK at the door. O'RYAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. O'Ryan rises, goes to the door... as Mackelway unholsters gun. O'Ryan opens the door. Standing here is a COED, with backpack. She looks confused. COED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I'm sorry. I was looking for Professor--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like that, O'Ryan has bolted past the Coed, literall tossing her onto Mackelway, exploding into the hall. She screams. Mackelway grabs her, moves her aside as gent time allows, then blows out of the room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O'Ryan turns a corner, vanishing. Mackelway follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mackelway finds himself facing another endless corridor: door after another, for what seems like a mile. But no O' Then Mackelway spots an EXIT SIGN. A stairwell...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mackelway enters. The stairs go six stories UP from here. and one story DOWN. A sub-basement. It's a guess. He descends, gun drawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mackelway emerges. "B-2" looks a lot like B-1: long and endless. We hear air moving around us, pipes carrying wat the wheezing of an old generator... And, on all sides of us, DOOES, a mile of them: maintenan offices, supply rooms, labs. He opens one - a janitor's supply. No one in here. Tries another door. Locked. A second. Locked. A third. Lo Air sucks through a corridor around us. He thinks he hear footsteps around a corner. Runs at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. No one. Just another vast corridor. More doors. Then, a sound. GLASS, shattering on the floor. He runs do the corridor, passing a long metal CAGE that houses this building's FIVE FURNACES. They're old and wheezy. It's dark behind them, shadowy. Not a bad place to hide. Farther down the corridor is another door - made of frost glass. A sign on it reads "Neuropsychiatric Lab." That's the sound came from... he thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mackelway enters. The lab is dark. He throws on every lig switch within reach... and finds himself standing over th shards of what used to be a GLASS BEAKER. So he's in the right place. He scans it: five rows of wor stations, ten microscopes per row, each with a sink besid Lining the walls are wide CABINETS. But there's also a MINI-LIBRARY down here: Four rows of BOOKSHELVES, housing medical journals. These are the "sta perfect for hiding behind. He plunges in. Row #1. Doesn't see anyone. Then Row #2, R #3, Row #4. Okay, the stacks check out... He walks along the rows of work-stations, scanning, crouc nudging open cabinets. One has been opened: Bottles of SOLUTIONS sit inside it. And a JAR that's been unsealed: It's got GAUZE PADS in it... In the back of the room, an INSTRUCTOR'S DESK awaits. It' tall enough to hide beneath. Mackelway slinks around it. Kneels down, looking into darkness... Then, a NOISE. The FRONT DOOR of this lab just swung open And O'Ryan just bolted out. Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mackelway emerges from the lab. Those furnaces whine besi him on the other side of that cage. But a GATE on that ca has been left ajar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five furnaces, separated from the sub-basement corridor b steel mesh. Mackelway enters. A few meager BULBS burn. He moves amidst shadow and noise: the chugging of engines humming, the wheezing, a slight vibration to the floor be us. He walks along the edge of Furnace #1... ...and is assaulted, from above. O'Ryan falls on him, knocking Mackelway hard into the sha CORNER of that furnace, then down to the ground. Mackelwa gun skids across the floor. And his mouth, suddenly, has been covered with gauze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to fight back... but suddenly he finds that his is swimming. Something's on that gauze. The room is getti fuzzy. We see the belly of a furnace - flames, heat. Then our ow BLOOD... (Mackelway's CHEST was torn open by the corner o that furnace.) Wait. Did we just see the glint of a KNIFE O'Ryan is leaning over us, in utter control. Then O'Ryan's head turns, abruptly - at the sound of FOOTSTEPS. And we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! You! What're you doing down here! We turn, groggily. TWO JANITORS rush toward us, keys jang It's all foggy, wavy, distorted. We see O'Ryan RISE. Then everything goes black...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mackelway's head is ringing. Feels like he can hear electricity in the walls around him. Slowly, he awakens. him are fluorescent lights. Monitors blink... Fran is here. So's Charlton. Mackelway tries to sit up. T shock of pain from his chest stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How ya doin'? Mackelway half-nods. His chest is bandaged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna need everything you can remember about this guy, Tom. Physical description, any kind of distinguishing characteristics. That was terse. Charlton looks pretty pissed-off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scratchy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The suspect fled. Couple janitors walked in on it. (before Mack can ask:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLTON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're fine. But the description they gave of him wasn't worth a damn. Mackelway nods. CHARLTON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Case you're curious the real Professor Daitz is on sabbatical, out of the country. We can't find him. (Mackelway nods) Whose idea was it to meet there? MACKELWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His, Sir. CHARLTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Did he ask you to come alone? MACKELWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Sir. CHARLTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you figured you'd get a bigger pat on the head if you wrapped this whole thing up without any help - is that it? The truth? Charlton has him pegged. But: FRAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I'm the one who took the call. Agent Mackelway was acting under the assumption that I'd already checked the guy out. We're both to blame. Hold it. That was a major exaggeration, if not an outrigh lie. Mackelway eyes her, thrown. She's poker-faced. Charlton, however, seems unmoved... CHARLTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Agent Mackelway attend the interview unaccompanied? FRAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) Yes, Sir. CHARLTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then whose fuck-up is it? Mackelway eyes her: "Thanks for trying." She nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at Charlton)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was... poor judgment, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna work alone, start your own agency. Mackelway can do nothing but nod. Then, bailing him out, another COMPOSITE ARTIST enters, tools in hand. Charlton sighs, frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: Composite Artist)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get you two started. Composite Artist is ready to begin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lively Sunday Service. Lots of Baptists, singing a rous spiritual. Music and praise filling the room. We move along the pews, until we came to the very back ro There, one man sits. Alone. Quiet. O'Ryan. Odd expression on his face - it's as if he can't hear thi rousing music, or feel the power of this place. People in next row are stomping their feet. Music soars. But O'Ryan just drops his head, slowly... and begins to W in the middle of this boisterous congregation. Outside, an 18-WHEEL TRUCK can be heard, rumbling by with great force. No one else in here seems to hear it. But O'Ryan shuts his eyes tight, grieving, sobbing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That TRUCK has just thundered by, leaving a swirl of debr its wake. We TILT UP from it... to find that those STORMC once in the distance are upon us now. And they are pulsing with menace. Rain, wind, lightning, thunder. Like a black wave, about to descend...

dialogues.speaker: WITH/INT. FBI OFFICE
dialogues.text: One of those five FAX MACHINES begins to ring. Then it be to PRINT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a Sunday. No one's here... but we get a look at what coming in. Same TOP-SHEET again: "Attention Agent Thomas Mackelway" etc. CONTINUE INTERCUT: this incoming fax, set against a few tableaus of Americana. Innocence...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A high school MARCHING BAND is out here, practicing. Cheerleaders work on their routines nearby. Then a LOUD WHISTLE SOUNDS. It's the BAND-LEADER, who is taking note of the weather gathering overhead. The music the band ceases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody into the gym! The band-members start to move. LIGHTNING erupts overhead

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An unnamed MOTHER emerges onto her back-porch, where her YEAR OLD DAUGHTER is having a playdate with a FRIEND. This house borders a wooded area. That wind is starting t make the trees swirl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girls, I want you to come in now. Startin' to rain. The girls sigh, disappointed, deciding instead to hide themselves inside the TENT they've erected out here. They giggle. The mother doesn't. CONTINUE INTERCUT:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That fax is now printing page after page. Photos with HAV SEEN ME? across the top and vitals across the bottom. But this time the transmission isn't stopping at five. Th are at least TEN sitting in the tray. Maybe twenty. Faces Eyes. Stats. Locations. Innocence violated...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SOCCER GAME's been called in the middle of the Second H PARENTS and their uniformed 12 YEAR-OLDS scatter. RAIN is pouring down now, blown sideways by that wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That massive, gleaming beast that rumbled past the church rolls right by this park - as all of those kids and their parents scramble for the shelter of their cars. The windshield wipers on this truck push water away, givi a clear look at the wet suburban chaos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The faithful in here keep singing, their voices full with praise - despite the heavy weather outside. They feel saf here. We move along the PEWS... ...until we find O'Ryan's. He's not here anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O'Ryan leans against the door of the church, pelted by th heavy rain. BAM! Here comes those IMAGES AGAIN:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tall wheat, whipped by wind and rain. A muzzle-flash. The sound of a body slumping hard to the ground. ...and Mackelway, looking over us. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're back with O'Ryan. He leans against the door, his torment constant. He walks away from the church, into that heavy rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fax tray has overflown onto the floor - 200 more phot 200 more HAVE YOU SEEN ME's. Forgotten victims. We hear a rumble from that 18-WHEELER. END INTERCUT...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now there are 800 YELLOW PINS stuck in this map - one for every single FAX or LETTER that's been received in the pa weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 800 faces. 800 HAVE YOU SEEN ME's, represented by 800 pin 800 cities. It's like a national plague. Mackelway sits, examining it soberly. His chest-wound is killing him. (We see a thick bandage beneath his shirt.) In his pocket now is a bottle of PRESCRIPTION PILLS. Perc He slugs one down without water, his eyes never straying that map. Beside it is a COMPOSITE DRAWING from O'Ryan, taken from Mackelway's description. It's dead-on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the lone source of light on an otherwise dark str of road. Mackelway's Yukon pulls up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardly a sound in here. Mackelway stands at the register, paying for his TAKE-OUT. Another night with nothing but h thoughts for company. Great. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agent Mackelway? It's Katie, the receptionist from his office - sitting by herself in a nearby booth. Mackelway smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inexpensive, but furnished with all the touches that Mackelway's apartment lacks: flea-market stuff, lace, ant books, photos from other eras. Character. And candles. Lots of candles. They throw SHADOWS of Macke and Katie all over the walls. An odd MUSIC fills the room, coming from a BOOM-BOX on th floor. It's a rhythmic Navajo CHANT, with Native-American drums providing the pulse.
